Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms of Nanoparticle Generation by Laser Ablation of Thin Films in Liquids

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will support a well-integrated collaborative experimental ? computational study of the mechanisms of nanoparticle generation in short pulse laser ablation of thin metal films and multi-layers in a liquid environment. The key processes that control the generation of nanoparticles will be investigated in large-scale atomistic simulations and experiments performed for thin film targets embedded in common liquids, such as water, acetone, and toluene, and irradiated by short (femtosecond to nanosecond) laser pulses. The detailed microscopic information on highly non-equilibrium processes of laser ablation and nanoparticle formation, revealed in the simulations, will be used to guide the experimental exploration of conditions that ensure fine control over the nanoparticle size distribution, structure and composition. The role of the spatial confinement of the deposited laser energy within the irradiated films and the interaction of the ejected ablation plume with liquid environment are among the key questions to be investigated computationally and in experiments.

The results of this study will provide guidance for the design of experimental setups optimized for the generation of nanoparticles with structure and composition meeting the needs of particular applications. This will enable individual researchers to produce nanoparticles for their research projects that are not readily available commercially, or if they are, at a great cost. The generation of nanoparticles with a narrow size distribution and free of contaminants has a good potential to impact many applications, including biomedical research, nanoengineering of advanced materials, optoelectronics, and surface catalysis. The close interaction between Rutgers-Camden, a predominantly undergraduate institution, and the University of Virginia, a research-oriented institution, will provide unique educational opportunities to a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability of short pulse laser ablation in liquids to produce clean colloidal nanoparticles and unusual surface morphology has been employed in a broad range of practical applications in various fields, including biomedicine, chemical catalysis, and plasmonics.  Nanoparticle generation through pulsed laser ablation in liquids, in particular, has emerged as a promising technique featuring a number of advantages with respect to traditional chemical processing methods.  While, experimentally, the presence of the liquid environment has been demonstrated to strongly affect the nanoparticle size distributions and microstructure of laser-modified surfaces, the fundamental mechanisms of the laser – materials interactions in liquids and the key processes that control the nanoparticle structure, composition, and size distribution are not yet fully understood.

In the NSF-sponsored research, Professor Zhigilei and his team at the University of Virginia are developing and applying advanced computational models capable of realistic simulation of laser ablation and processing of metals in liquid environment.  The results obtained in this project are reported in 17 publications (14 journal papers and 3 book chapters), and are presented in 30 contributed conference presentations, 22 invited talks (4 of which are given by graduate students supported by this award), 4 keynote/plenary talks, and 4 tutorials.  Two students supported by this award defended their PhD theses.

One example of the research outcome of this project is the prediction of a key role of hydrodynamic instabilities (a combination of the Rayleigh–Taylor and Richtmyer–Meshkov hydrodynamic instabilities at the interface between ablation plume and liquid environment) in the generation of large nanoparticles in pulsed laser ablation in liquids.  This computational prediction provides a plausible explanation for experimental observations of bimodal nanoparticle size distributions in short pulse laser ablation experiments.  The results are reported in two journal papers [J. Phys. Chem. C 121, 16549-16567, 2017; J. Colloid Interface Sci. 489, 3-17, 2017] and a chapter in a book published by Pan Stanford in 2017 and entitled Pulsed Laser Ablation: Advances and Applications in Nanoparticles and Nanostructuring Thin Films (Chapter 12, pp. 421-466).  A figure illustrating this novel and unexpected mechanism of nanoparticle generation was selected as a cover image for August 3, 2017 issue of the Journal of Physical Chemistry C.

The broader impacts of this program are in the implications of the physical insights revealed in this project for the advancement of laser applications based on laser processing of metal surfaces and generation of nanoparticles by laser ablation in liquids.  On the educational/outreach side, the project has provided training and multidisciplinary research experience to three graduate students and three undergraduate students.  The graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project received a number of awards at the university level as well as at the national and international research meetings, including the Materials Science and Engineering Distinguished Undergraduate Award, UVa Double Hoo Research Award (to support joint undergraduate – graduate research), the UVa Engineering Science Symposium award, two Undergraduate Summer Research Awards from the NanoSTAR Institute (UVa), UVa Engineering Foundation Graduate Fellowship, the First Place poster award at the International High Power Laser Ablation Symposia, Alcoa Undergraduate Research Fellowship, and Roger Kelly Award for the Best Graduate Student presentation at the International School on Laser-Surface Interactions for New Materials Production.  Most students supported by this grant were trained in parallel programming and used high-performance computing resources at the NSF-supported Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE).  Some of the students participated in the Summer Supercomputing Institute at Texas Advanced Computing Center, the Argonne Training Program on Extreme-Scale Computing, Titan Users and Developers Workshop at the Oak Ridge Leadership Computational Facility, and gave presentations at a Focus Session on “Petascale Science and Beyond” of the APS March Meeting.

The project also enabled an active participation of the PI in the establishment of the Venice International School on Lasers in Materials Science.  The PI has served as lecturer (2008-present) and co-director (2012, 2018) of the School that aims to educate graduate students in the fundamental principles of laser-materials interactions and bring them up to date with the current state-of-the art in laser processing of materials. More than 170 students from many different countries have attended this School so far. NSF supported participation U.S. students (6 in 2012 and 10 in 2016) through a supplemental travel award provided to the PI, who organized the trips. The PI also co-edited a book based on lectures given at the School and published in Springer Series in Materials Science in 2014.  A new book based on the lectures given in 2016 is currently in preparation.
